snippet: Airstrikes alone may not be enough to root out battle-hardened Malian rebels, who have spent months accumulating arms, constructing defenses and reinforcing their ranks.
abstract: French military airstrikes in Mali alone may not be enough to root out battle-hardened Islamist rebels; insurgents have spent months accumulating arms, constructing defenses and reinforcing their ranks; officials say effort to contain their southern advance toward capital of Bamako is proving more challenging than anticipated.

byline.original: By ADAM NOSSITER and ERIC SCHMITT
byline.contributor: Adam Nossiter reported from Bamako, and Eric Schmitt from Washington. Steven Erlanger and Scott Sayare contributed reporting from Paris, and Elisabeth Bumiller from Madrid.

lead_paragraph: Airstrikes alone may not be enough to root out battle-hardened Malian rebels, who have spent months accumulating arms, constructing defenses and reinforcing their ranks.

headline.seo: Mali Rebels Dig In and Blend In for a Long Struggle
headline.main: Facing the French, Mali Rebels Dig In and Blend In
headline.print_headline: Facing French, Mali Rebels Dig In and Blend In

keywords.value: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
keywords.name: organizations
